articles.headline: With Manchin Out, Democrats’ Path to Holding the Senate Is Narrow
articles.snippet: While the party will be on defense in every competitive race, Republicans face some messy primaries and a recent history of nominating extreme candidates who have lost key contests.
articles.abstract: While the party will be on defense in every competitive race, Republicans face some messy primaries and a recent history of nominating extreme candidates who have lost key contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin III said he decided to forgo re-election because he’d accomplished all his goals. But for the Democrats he’s leaving behind in Washington, the work to hold the party’s already slim Senate majority is just beginning.
articles.byline: By Michael C. Bender and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Gaza City Hospitals Are Caught in Deadly Crossfire
articles.snippet: Battling Hamas fighters, Israeli forces are “closing in” on hospitals where thousands of people are stranded, while the chief U.S. diplomat says “far too many Palestinians have been killed.”
articles.abstract: Battling Hamas fighters, Israeli forces are “closing in” on hospitals where thousands of people are stranded, while the chief U.S. diplomat says “far too many Palestinians have been killed.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Gaza City’s hospitals were increasingly under siege on Friday, with hundreds of seriously ill and wounded patients and thousands of displaced people stranded on hospital grounds as intense, close-quarters combat between Israeli troops and Hamas fighters raged around them.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Aaron Boxerman, Malachy Browne and Neil Collier

articles.headline: Street Battles Rage in Gaza City Ruins, as Residents Flee on Foot
articles.snippet: The Biden administration, which has pressed Israel to do more to safeguard civilian lives, said Israel had agreed to steps to help people flee the northern Gaza Strip and receive aid.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration, which has pressed Israel to do more to safeguard civilian lives, said Israel had agreed to steps to help people flee the northern Gaza Strip and receive aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers and armored vehicles have engaged Hamas fighters in days of running gun battles in Gaza City, fighting through rubble-filled streets and blasted-out buildings for control of the Gaza Strip’s largest urban center and the militants’ main stronghold.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Mint, the Budgeting App, Is Going Away. Here Are Some Alternatives.
articles.snippet: Finding a money app that works best for you requires personal testing. We asked popular competitors to Mint why you should try their offerings.
articles.abstract: Finding a money app that works best for you requires personal testing. We asked popular competitors to Mint why you should try their offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The demise of Mint, the beloved budgeting app, has caused its millions of users to consider alternatives. That makes it as good a time as any for everyone to consider a money management tool.

articles.headline: One Year in the Infuriating and Humiliating Search for a Job in South Africa
articles.snippet: Portia Stafford has a high school diploma in hospitality and three certificates from job training programs. She is among a generation of ambitious Africans who spend their days chasing an elusive opening.
articles.abstract: Portia Stafford has a high school diploma in hospitality and three certificates from job training programs. She is among a generation of ambitious Africans who spend their days chasing an elusive opening.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a part of a series on how Africa’s youth boom is changing the continent, and beyond.
articles.byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Gulshan Khan

articles.headline: They Wanted to Get Sober. They Got a Nightmare Instead.
articles.snippet: Arizona spent $1 billion on addiction treatment, much of it fraudulent, officials said. Scores of Native Americans who sought help are still struggling with untreated addiction — and some died in rehab.
articles.abstract: Arizona spent $1 billion on addiction treatment, much of it fraudulent, officials said. Scores of Native Americans who sought help are still struggling with untreated addiction — and some died in rehab.
articles.lead_paragraph: The white vans were the first thing people noticed.

articles.headline: How Millions of Borrowers Got $127 Billion in Student Loans Canceled
articles.snippet: The Biden administration may have been blocked from canceling debt for tens of millions of borrowers by the Supreme Court, but it has still managed to eliminate billions in education debt.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration may have been blocked from canceling debt for tens of millions of borrowers by the Supreme Court, but it has still managed to eliminate billions in education debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s $400 billion plan to forgive up to $20,000 in federal student loan debt for 43 million borrowers, the prospect of substantive debt relief appeared to vanish.

articles.headline: Sweeping Raids, Giant Camps and Mass Deportations: Inside Trump’s 2025 Immigration Plans
articles.snippet: If he regains power, Donald Trump wants not only to revive some of the immigration policies criticized as draconian during his presidency, but expand and toughen them.
articles.abstract: If he regains power, Donald Trump wants not only to revive some of the immigration policies criticized as draconian during his presidency, but expand and toughen them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is planning an extreme expansion of his first-term crackdown on immigration if he returns to power in 2025 — including preparing to round up undocumented people already in the United States on a vast scale and detain them in sprawling camps while they wait to be expelled.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: Texas Bishop Loudly Critical of the Pope Is Removed
articles.snippet: Bishop Joseph Strickland was a highly prominent figure among traditionalist American Catholics who see Pope Francis as too liberal.
articles.abstract: Bishop Joseph Strickland was a highly prominent figure among traditionalist American Catholics who see Pope Francis as too liberal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pope Francis fired on Saturday a bishop in Texas who was one of his loudest American critics within the Catholic Church, a highly rare dismissal that appeared to reflect the growing rift between the Vatican and a more conservative wing of the church.
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: ‘The Climate’s No Good’: The Hunt for White Truffles Gets Pricier
articles.snippet: Climate change in Italy has come for one of the world’s most sought-after delicacies. Foodies will probably see the impact when the check comes.
articles.abstract: Climate change in Italy has come for one of the world’s most sought-after delicacies. Foodies will probably see the impact when the check comes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Primo and Scilla led the way deeper into the woods near Amandola, in central Italy. Across a gurgling brook, up a muddy slope, over mossy tree limbs, through a tangle of brambles and vines, the dogs covered acres of terrain. For nearly three hours, their olfactory senses were on high alert for white truffles, a delicacy with soaring prices, in large part because they are under extreme threat by climate change.

articles.headline: Gaza Hospitals Near Collapse as Fighting Rages Nearby
articles.snippet: Facing power outages and shortages of food, water and medical supplies, hospitals are struggling just to keep patients alive, Gazan health authorities say.
articles.abstract: Facing power outages and shortages of food, water and medical supplies, hospitals are struggling just to keep patients alive, Gazan health authorities say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Operations at Gaza’s main hospital were showing signs of collapse on Saturday, with its director and the Gazan Health Ministry describing power outages, shortages of water and medicine and a crisis in treating seriously wounded patients and vulnerable children, while battles between Israeli troops and Hamas fighters raged ever closer.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim, Ameera Harouda and Alan Yuhas

articles.headline: Army Ammunition Plant Is Tied to Mass Shootings Across the U.S.
articles.snippet: The site was built for the military, but commercial sales are booming with little public accountability. Rounds have been bought by murderers, antigovernment groups and others.
articles.abstract: The site was built for the military, but commercial sales are booming with little public accountability. Rounds have been bought by murderers, antigovernment groups and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christopher Hixon, a 27-year veteran of the Navy who served in the Persian Gulf, trained with government ammunition that typically had a distinctive “LC” marking on its brass casings.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Emily Rhyne

articles.headline: The Corner Lot Where All the World’s Vegemite Comes From
articles.snippet: First concocted a century ago, the spread is widely adored by Australians — and loathed by almost everyone else.
articles.abstract: First concocted a century ago, the spread is widely adored by Australians — and loathed by almost everyone else.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just off Australia’s largest container port lies a sickle-shaped neighborhood with a scent so distinctive that passing taxi drivers will sometimes roll down their windows for a whiff of the rich and unmistakably beery aroma.
articles.byline: By Natasha Frost and Abigail Varney

articles.headline: You Paid $1,000 for an iPhone, but Apple Still Controls It
articles.snippet: The company codes its devices with software that complicates repairs by triggering safety warnings and malfunctions.
articles.abstract: The company codes its devices with software that complicates repairs by triggering safety warnings and malfunctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a decade, it was easy to get help repairing an iPhone. Cracked screens could be replaced in minutes, and broken cameras could be exchanged without a hitch.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle, Ella Koeze and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Her Livelihood? Hunting Pythons in the Dead of Night.
articles.snippet: Amy Siewe teaches people how to find and euthanize invasive Burmese pythons, which have been so successful at adapting to Florida that they appear here to stay.
articles.abstract: Amy Siewe teaches people how to find and euthanize invasive Burmese pythons, which have been so successful at adapting to Florida that they appear here to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: An unexpected chill can fall over the Florida Everglades late at night. Stars speckle the sky. Frogs croak and croak, their mating calls echoing in the air.

articles.headline: Vermont May Be the Face of a Long-Term U.S. Labor Shortage
articles.snippet: Employers are pulling out all the stops to attract workers as the state’s population grows older, offering a likely glimpse of the country’s future.
articles.abstract: Employers are pulling out all the stops to attract workers as the state’s population grows older, offering a likely glimpse of the country’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Lake Champlain Chocolates, the owners take shifts stacking boxes in the warehouse. At Burlington Bagel Bakery, a sign in the window advertises wages starting at $25 an hour. Central Vermont Medical Center is training administrative employees to become nurses. Cabot Creamery is bringing workers from out of state to package its signature blocks of Cheddar cheese.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Jeanna Smialek and Hilary Swift

articles.headline: Israeli Forces Near a Struggling Hospital They Say Covers a Hamas Complex
articles.snippet: Israeli officials say that Hamas has built a complex under Al Shifa, a major Gaza hospital. Hamas denies it is operating from beneath the hospital, whose patients face dire conditions amid power cuts.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials say that Hamas has built a complex under Al Shifa, a major Gaza hospital. Hamas denies it is operating from beneath the hospital, whose patients face dire conditions amid power cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Israel consolidating its hold on northern Gaza, its forces are closing in on a sprawling medical center that for Israelis and Palestinians alike has emerged as a symbol of the other side’s inhumanity.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Behind Public Assurances, Xi Jinping Has Spread Grim Views on U.S.
articles.snippet: Speeches by the Chinese leader show how he was bracing for an intensifying rivalry with the United States from early in his rule.
articles.abstract: Speeches by the Chinese leader show how he was bracing for an intensifying rivalry with the United States from early in his rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Xi Jinping of China made his first state visit to the United States in 2015, he wrapped his demands for respect in reassurances.

articles.headline: Polluting Industries Say the Cost of Cleaner Air Is Too High
articles.snippet: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.
articles.abstract: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is about to announce new regulations governing soot — the particles that trucks, farms, factories, wildfires, power plants and dusty roads generate. By law, the agency isn’t supposed to consider the impact on polluting industries. In practice, it does — and those industries are warning of dire economic consequences.
